		<div style="font-family: Open Sans, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;">
			<h4 style="font-weight:700; font-size:1.5rem; letter-spacing:-0.03em; margin-bottom:1rem;">Why is Christian Science in our name?</h4>
			<p style="padding-bottom:.75rem; line-height:1.6;">Our name is about honesty. The Monitor is owned by The Christian Science Church, and we’ve always been transparent about that.</p>
			<p style="padding-bottom:.75rem; line-height:1.6;">The Church publishes the Monitor because it sees good journalism as vital to progress in the world. Since 1908, we’ve aimed “to injure no man, but to bless all mankind,” as our founder, Mary Baker Eddy, put it.</p>
			<p style="padding-bottom:.75rem; line-height:1.6;">Here, you’ll find award-winning journalism not driven by commercial influences – a news organization that takes seriously its mission to uplift the world by seeking solutions and finding reasons for credible hope.</p>
			<a href="/values?icid=mega-why:csm-name:values" class="button_link" style="display:inline-block; background-color:#2A2A2A; font-size:14px; color:#fefefe; padding: 0.9em 1.4em 1em 1.4em; border-radius: 3px;">Explore values journalism</a>
			<a href="/About?icid=mega-why:csm-name:about" style="color: black; padding-bottom: 1px; font-size: 14px; border-bottom: 1px solid black; margin-left:20px;">About us</a>

<div class="ezc-ddp-intro ezv-embed col-12 col-lg-3 menu-block menu-daily ">

	
				<div class="date">October 23, 2024</div>
	
    		<div class="title">A radical makeover</div>
    
        	<div class="intro-clamp">
		<p class="intro">        
Have you heard of Javier Milei? He’s the president of Argentina, about to wrap up his first and very consequential year in office. Howard LaFranchi visited Buenos Aires recently and took stock of Mr. Milei’s no-holds-barred drive to radically reorganize the government and reimagine a boom-and-bust, hyperinflation-riddled economy. His often painful pursuit of wrenching change is thrilling some; others reject his rough talk and divisive measures.It’s a major revolution led by a brash economist and former lead singer in a Rolling Stones cover band. One observer notes that Mr. Milei believes he’s going to save the West with his model. See what you think.    </p>
	</div>

</div>			</div>

<script>

	function submitForm( form )
	{
		let newsletterEmailField = form.querySelector('input[type="email"]');

		if (newsletterEmailField !== undefined )
		{
			let newsletterEmail = newsletterEmailField.value,
				rootURL = '/monitornewsletters?email=',
				newsletterSections = getCheckedNewsletters(form),
				trackingParam = getParam(form);

			if ( newsletterEmail !== undefined )
			{
				let signUpURL = rootURL + encodeURIComponent(newsletterEmail) + newsletterSections + trackingParam;
				window.location = signUpURL;
			}
		}
	}

	function removeMultipleListings()
	{
		let listings = document.querySelectorAll('#newsletter-listing');
		if ( listings.length > 1 )
		{
			for(let x=1; x<listings.length; x++)
			{
				listings[x].remove();
			}
		}
	}

	function getCheckedNewsletters( form )
	{
		let newsletterSections = '';
		if( form.hasAttribute('data-selection') )
		{
			let dataSelection = form.getAttribute('data-selection');
			if(dataSelection.length > 0)
			{
				dataSelection.split(' ').forEach( newsletter =>
				{
					newsletterSections += `&${newsletter}=true`;
				})
			}
		}
		return newsletterSections;
	}

	function getParam( form )
	{
		let param = setDefaultParam( form.parentElement );
		let newsletterBannerParent = form.parentElement.parentElement;
		if ( newsletterBannerParent.classList.contains( 'param-added' ) )
		{
			param = '&icid=mkt:web:' + newsletterBannerParent.getAttribute('data-param');
		}
		return param;
	}

	function setDefaultParam( formContainer )
	{
		let defaultParam = '&icid=mkt:web:banner',
			pageBody = document.querySelector('body');

		if ( formContainer )
		{
			if ( formContainer.classList.contains( 'books' ) )
			{
				defaultParam = '&icid=mkt:web:books';
			}
			else if ( formContainer.classList.contains( 'politics' ) )
			{
				defaultParam = '&icid=mkt:web:politics';
			}
			else if ( formContainer.classList.contains( 'culture-learning' ) )
			{
				defaultParam = '&icid=mkt:web:culture-learning';
			}
			else if ( formContainer.classList.contains( 'science' ) )
			{
				defaultParam = '&icid=mkt:web:science-nature';
			}
			else if ( formContainer.classList.contains( 'csperspective' ) )
			{
				defaultParam = '&icid=mkt:web:csp';
			}
			else if ( formContainer.classList.contains( 'commentary' ) )
			{
				defaultParam = '&icid=mkt:web:commentary';
			}
			else if ( formContainer.classList.contains( 'highlights' ) )
			{
				defaultParam = '&icid=mkt:web:highlights';
			}
		}

		if ( pageBody.classList.contains( 'ezc-frontpage' ) )
		{
			defaultParam = '&icid=mkt:web:frontpage';
		}
		return defaultParam;
	}

	function addFormEventListener()
	{
		let newsletterBanners = document.querySelectorAll('.newsletter-banner:not(.subscribe):not(.free-trial) form');
		newsletterBanners.forEach( newsletterBanner =>
		{
			if( newsletterBanner.getAttribute('sub-event') !== 'true' )
			{
				newsletterBanner.addEventListener( 'submit', ( e ) =>
				{
					e.preventDefault();
					submitForm( newsletterBanner );
					newsletterBanner.innerHTML = '<div style="font-weight:600;" class="text-center">Thank you for signing up for a free Monitor Newsletter!</div>';
				});
				newsletterBanner.setAttribute('sub-event','true');
			}
		});
	}

	if ( window.location.href.indexOf('kwc2c') > -1 )
	{
		let allNewslettersBanners = document.querySelectorAll(".newsletter-banner");
		allNewslettersBanners.remove();
	}


	document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', () =>
	{
		removeMultipleListings();
		addFormEventListener();
		try
		{
			let salesforce_id = _satellite.getVar('Query String - SFMC Subscriber ID');
			if ( salesforce_id )
			{
				let pagePath = csmJs.pageData.sections;

				if ( pagePath.indexOf( 'Books' ) > -1 )
				{
					csmJs.cta.changeBanner( 'books' );
				}
				else if ( pagePath.indexOf( 'Politics' ) > -1 )
				{
					csmJs.cta.changeBanner( 'politics' );
				}
				else if ( pagePath.indexOf( 'Education' ) > -1 ||
					pagePath.indexOf( 'The Culture' ) > -1 )
				{
					csmJs.cta.changeBanner( 'culture-learning' );
				}
				else if ( pagePath.indexOf( 'Science' ) > -1 ||
					pagePath.indexOf( 'Environment' ) > -1 ||
					pagePath.indexOf( 'Technology' ) > -1 )
				{
					csmJs.cta.changeBanner( 'science' );
				}
				else if ( pagePath.indexOf( 'A Christian Science Perspective' ) > -1 )
				{
					csmJs.cta.changeBanner( 'csperspective' );
				}
				else if ( pagePath.indexOf( 'Commentary' ) > -1 )
				{
					csmJs.cta.changeBanner( 'commentary' );
				}
				else
				{
					csmJs.cta.changeBanner( 'highlights' );
				}
			}
		}
		catch ( error )
		{
			console.warn( error );
		}
	}, false);
</script>

			<div class="row">
				<div class="small-centered small-11 text-center columns">
					<h1 id="headline" class="eza-title">
													
Stealing US business secrets: Experts ID two huge cyber 'gangs' in China											</h1>
				</div>
			</div>

			
							<div class="row">
					<div id="summary" class="eza-summary small-centered eza-body small-11 hide-for-paywall">
						<div>
							
<p>Two large operations in China account for 90 percent of cyberespionage against US business, one expert says. Research suggests the scope of the operations could be breathtaking.</p>						</div>
					</div>
				</div>
			
			
						<div class="row">
				<div id="main-media" class="small-12 small-centered medium-9 large-7 columns">
					<div class="default-slick-slider">
													<div>
													
<figure class="embed ezc-image ">
																															
	
	
	
	
	
	
	
	
	
		
		
		<picture>
			<!--[if IE 9]><video style="display: none;"><![endif]-->
			
				
								
															
				
				
																			
				
				
				<source
					media="(max-width: 40em)"
					data-srcset="//images.csmonitor.com/csm/2012/09/0914-CHINA-GOOGLE-Elderwood.jpg?alias=standard_600x400nc" />
			
				
								
															
				
				
																			
				
				
				<source
					media="(max-width: 64em)"
					data-srcset="//images.csmonitor.com/csm/2012/09/0914-CHINA-GOOGLE-Elderwood.jpg?alias=standard_900x600nc" />

					data-srcset="//images.csmonitor.com/csm/2012/09/0914-CHINA-GOOGLE-Elderwood.jpg?alias=standard_900x600nc" />
						<!--[if IE 9]></video><![endif]-->

			
			
																																																							
			<img
				src="//images.csmonitor.com/csm/2012/09/0914-CHINA-GOOGLE-Elderwood.jpg?alias=standard_900x600nc"
				data-sizes="auto"
				class=" "
				alt="">
		</picture>

			</figure>
	<div class="image-data">

		
					<div class="source-data">
									<div class="fullscreen">
						<a data-toggle="main-art-modal" title="full screen"><i class="icon-enlarge"></i></a>
					</div>
													<span class="divider">|</span>
													<div class="image-credit">			<span class="eza-credit">Ng Han Guan/AP/File</span></div>
							</div>
							<div class="caption-bar text-wrapper  ">
					<div class="eza-caption">Flowers are placed on the Google logo outside Google China headquarters in Beijing, China, on March 23, 2010. </div>
				</div>
						</div>							</div>
											</div>
					<div
						class="full reveal gallery-modal"
						id="main-art-modal"
						data-reveal
						data-content="/layout/set/plain/USA/2012/0914/Stealing-US-business-secrets-Experts-ID-two-huge-cyber-gangs-in-China/(view)/gallery"
					>

			<div class="row mt-1 ">
				
																				<section class="large-10 large-offset-1 small-centered float-left columns">
					
					<div class="story-head row"> 
													
						
<ul class="story-bylines small-centered medium-11 large-8 text-center" data-widget-name="byline">
			
		
							
		
		
		
				<li class="author ">
						<div>
				<span class="pre-byline">By </span>				<span class="staff-name">Mark Clayton</span>
				<span class="staffline">Staff writer</span>							</div>
		</li>

		
																	
</ul>																	</div> 

					<p class="text-center story-date">
						<span class="pubdata">
	<time
	datetime="2012-09-14T16:43:00-04:00"
	title="Published: September 14, 2012 4:43 pm EDT">
    		Sept. 14, 2012, 4:43 p.m. ET
	</time>

</span>
											</p>

															
					<div class="row">
						<div class="small-centered small-12 columns">
														<div class="story-two eza-body small-11 small-centered medium-10 large-12 deep-read story-body-toggle-content prem default truncate-for-paywall">
																<p>Sneaky Panda. The Elderwood Gang. The <a href="/csmlists/topic/Beijing" target="_self" class="inform_link" rel="nofollow">Beijing</a> Group.</p><p>These are three code names bestowed by <a href="/csmlists/topic/United+States" target="_self" class="inform_link" rel="nofollow">US</a> experts on a single cyberespionage organization that, from 9 to 5 Beijing time each day, is at work siphoning the crown jewels of US corporations' proprietary data out of their networks – and into computers in <a href="/csmlists/topic/China" target="_self" class="inform_link" rel="nofollow">China</a>.</p><p>In January 2010, Internet search giant <a href="/csmlists/topic/Google+Inc." target="_self" class="inform_link" rel="nofollow">Google</a> disclosed that someone had hacked into its network (not to mention 20 other tech companies). That someone was the Elderwood Gang, says a new report by <a href="/csmlists/topic/Symantec+Corporation" target="_self" class="inform_link" rel="nofollow">Symantec</a>, a cybersecurity company.</p><aside class="injection"></aside><p>The Symantec report hints at what other US cybersecurity experts are saying with increasing conviction: that Elderwood is one of two large Chinese economic cyberespionage organizations – employing perhaps hundreds of people – which are working to vacuum business ideas and advanced designs from American computer networks.</p><p>For example, these experts are now connecting Elderwood and a second Chinese hacking group to attacks on top cybersecurity company RSA, defense-industry giant <a href="/csmlists/topic/Lockheed+Martin+Corporation" target="_self" class="inform_link" rel="nofollow">Lockheed Martin</a>, and perhaps several US natural gas pipeline companies.</p><p>It has long been claimed by US cybersecurity experts that cyberspying to harvest intellectual property, rather than quick cash from online bank accounts, was a practice emanating mostly from China. Plausible deniability remains because attribution is so uncertain in cyberspace. Chinese embassy officials in <a href="/csmlists/topic/Washington,+DC" target="_self" class="inform_link" rel="nofollow">Washington</a> routinely deny any responsibility for cyberespionage on US targets.</p><aside class="injection"><div class="article-story-promo ezp-inbody-promo anonymous" data-widget-name="slot-a">
<div class="title">Recommended</div>
<div class="ezv-listing ezc-csm-story  with-thumbnail ezws-3"><a title="Elon Musk is spending big to boost Trump’s turnout. Republicans worry it might flop." class="ezc-csm-story-link" href="/USA/Politics/2024/1018/elon-musk-trump-ground-game-voter-turnout"><div class="story-thumbnail square_200x200"><img class=" lazyload" data-src="//images.csmonitor.com/csm/2024/10/1018%20NMUSK%20lede.jpg?alias=square_200x200" alt=""></div>
<div class="story-detail"><h3 class="story-headline"><span class="story_link">Elon Musk is spending big to boost Trump’s turnout. Republicans worry it might flop.</span></h3></div></a></div>
</div></aside><p>Yet there are signs now that the attribution problem is closer to being solved, US experts say.</p><p>"We're tracking over a dozen nation-state groups right now that are affiliated with China," says Dmitri Alperovitch, chief technology officer for CrowdStrike, a startup cybersecurity company focused on taking undisclosed "offensive" security measures. "We have a deep understanding of them and attribution down to the individual level. They're operating in China, and we're watching them. Even though they're unlikely be brought to justice in the US, we understand a lot today."</p><p>Among the 20 or so identifiable Chinese cyberespionage groups, the two that dwarf the others are the Elderwood Gang and the Comment Crew. The two have many different names, with researchers giving them different monikers. To Dell Secureworks cyber counterspy expert <a href="/csmlists/topic/Joe+Stewart" target="_self" class="inform_link" rel="nofollow">Joe Stewart</a>, they are the Beijing Group and the <a href="/csmlists/topic/Shanghai" target="_self" class="inform_link" rel="nofollow">Shanghai</a> Group because of where their activities seem to originate. To Mr. Alperovitch of CrowdStrike, they are Sneaky Panda and Comment Panda.</p><p>Symantec called the first group “Elderwood” because the name appears in a source-code variable used by the attackers. In Google's case, the gang reportedly made off with at least some of the search company's source code – secret algorithms that have made it so successful. Nobody knows exactly how much was stolen from the networks of the other companies.</p><p>Today, 2-1/2 years later, Google has abandoned the Chinese market, but Elderwood is alive and doing quite well, its cyberspies busy as ever, the Symantec analysis shows. Second-tier defense industry suppliers that make electronic or mechanical components for top defense companies are the gang's specialty. Those firms then become a cyber "stepping stone to gain access to top-tier defense contractors," the report says.</p><aside class="injection"><div class="article-story-promo ezp-inbody-promo anonymous" data-widget-name="slot-b">
<div class="title">Recommended</div>
<div class="ezv-listing ezc-csm-story  with-thumbnail ezws-3"><a title="In Gaza or Ukraine, peace can look impossible. Here, there’s hope." class="ezc-csm-story-link" href="/World/Europe/2024/1022/Geneva-Peace-Week-United-Nations"><div class="story-thumbnail square_200x200"><img class=" lazyload" data-src="//images.csmonitor.com/csm/2024/10/1183016_2_1021-Awwad-Geneva-Peace-Week_standard.jpg?alias=square_200x200" alt=""></div>
<div class="story-detail">
<span class="kicker value_kicker">Peace</span><h3 class="story-headline"><span class="story_link">In Gaza or Ukraine, peace can look impossible. Here, there’s hope.</span></h3>
</div></a></div>
</div></aside><p>But Elderwood's appetite for information is broad and its capacity far larger than the defense industry alone. So, in at least eight major "campaigns" in less than two years, the gang has slipped into the networks of US shipping, aeronautics, arms, energy, manufacturing, engineering, electronics, financial, and, of course, software companies, Symantec reports.</p><aside class="injection"></aside><p>In most cases, Elderwood uses a convincing "spear-phishing" fake e-mail to fool an employee into clicking an infected e-mailed link or into opening a Trojan software-infected attachment that creates a digital backdoor for the cyberspies. In many cases, these attacks have utilized costly "zero-day" malware that takes advantage of a previously unknown flaw against which no defense exists. Such technology would sell for at least six figures on the cyber black market, leading many to conclude the group is exceedingly well funded.</p><p>Lately, however, Elderwood has taken to infecting legitimate websites frequented by employees of the target company – a so-called "water hole" attack, just as lions stake out a watering hole for their prey. Elderwood infects these less-secure sites with malware that downloads to a computer that clicks on the site. After that, the gang snoops inside the network to which the infected computer is connected, finding and finally downloading executives' e-mails and critical documents on company plans, decisions, acquisitions, and product designs.</p><p>"Victims are attacked, not for petty crime or theft, but for the wholesale gathering of intelligence and intellectual property," Symantec reports. "The resources required to identify and acquire useful information – let alone analyze that information – could only be provided by a large criminal organization, attackers supported by a nation state, or a nation state itself."</p><aside class="injection"></aside><p>This sort of activity is hardly unknown to US cybersecurity experts, who have long dubbed it the "advanced persistent threat" – a euphemism taken to mean espionage threats originating from China. Mr. Stewart of Dell Secureworks has traced the activity of the Elderwood Gang (which he calls the Beijing Group) and the Comment Crew (which he calls the Shanghai Group) back to 2005-2006. He says they are responsible for perhaps 90 percent of all economic espionage against the US today.</p><div class="story-half"></div><p>"Both groups surface time and again in different reports you read," he says. "Someone discovers some malware and gives it a snazzy name. But it's all the same activity underneath."</p><p>Technical links – including IP addresses, domain names, malware signatures, and other technical factors – show Elderwood was behind the attack on Google, which is known as Operation Aurora, he says.</p><aside class="injection"></aside><p>Stewart also ties Elderwood to other major hacks, including one against Tibetan activists – the "GhostNet" global cyberespionage network documented by University of Toronto Researchers in 2010 – and the major hack of RSA, the <a href="/csmlists/topic/Bedford+(Massachusetts)" target="_self" class="inform_link" rel="nofollow">Bedford, Mass.</a>, cybersecurity subsidiary of <a href="/csmlists/topic/EMC+Corporation" target="_self" class="inform_link" rel="nofollow">EMC</a> corporation.</p><p>In 2010, Alperovitch of CrowdStrike was vice president of threat research for McAfee, the cybersecurity company that analyzed the Aurora intrusion at Google. He agrees with Stewart that the group behind Aurora is the same one that hacked RSA and later attempted to hack defense giant Lockheed Martin.</p><p>[<b>Editor's note:</b><i> </i><i>The original version of this story misidentified Mr. Alperovitch’s role at McAfee</i><i>.</i>]</p><aside class="injection"></aside><p>In 2011, while still at McAfee, he went on to reveal Comment Crew (which he calls Comment Panda) operating alongside Elderwood. It's called that because the group so often uses a technique involving internal software "comment" features on web pages as a tool to infiltrate target computers.</p><aside class="injection"><div class="article-story-promo ezp-inbody-promo anonymous" data-widget-name="slot-d">
<div class="title">Recommended</div>
<div class="ezv-listing ezc-csm-story  with-thumbnail ezws-3"><a title="In Norway, having a joyful, secure childhood is a right enshrined into law" class="ezc-csm-story-link" href="/World/Europe/2024/1015/norway-child-care-subsidy-universal-preschool"><div class="story-thumbnail square_200x200"><img class=" lazyload" data-src="//images.csmonitor.com/csm/2024/10/1014%20CNORWAY%20play%20LEDE.jpg?alias=square_200x200" alt=""></div>
<div class="story-detail">
<span class="kicker value_kicker">Community</span><h3 class="story-headline"><span class="story_link">In Norway, having a joyful, secure childhood is a right enshrined into law</span></h3>
</div></a></div>
</div></aside><p>Comment Crew, Alperovitch found, had infiltrated at least 72 organizations including defense companies, the <a href="/csmlists/topic/International+Olympic+Committee" target="_self" class="inform_link" rel="nofollow">International Olympic Committee</a>, and the <a href="/csmlists/topic/United+Nations" target="_self" class="inform_link" rel="nofollow">United Nations</a>. He dubbed Comment Crew's campaign Operation ShadyRAT – "RAT" standing for "remote access tool," the name for malware used to control computer systems remotely.</p><p>Stewart then discovered a flaw in the malicious software used by the Operation ShadyRAT operators, and that allowed him to track back pilfered data to the perpetrators' computer addresses in Shanghai.</p><aside class="injection"></aside><p>Both big hacker groups were involved in the RSA hack, he has concluded.</p><p>Evidence was already strong that at least one and perhaps both were involved in one of this year's major cyberespionage attacks – infiltrating the networks of US natural gas pipeline companies, an attack first reported by the Monitor in May.</p><p>Digital signatures, domain names, and other indicators used by the hackers in the RSA case, which were Chinese in origin, lined up with those in the pipeline case, experts told the Monitor at the time.</p><aside class="injection"></aside><p>"The indicators DHS provided to hunt for the gas-pipeline attackers included several that, when we checked them, turned out to be related to those used by the perpetrators of the RSA attack," Robert Huber, co-founder of Critical Intelligence, an <a href="/csmlists/topic/Idaho+Falls" target="_self" class="inform_link" rel="nofollow">Idaho Falls</a>, <a href="/csmlists/topic/Idaho" target="_self" class="inform_link" rel="nofollow">Idaho</a>, security company told the Monitor at the time. "It makes it highly likely that the same actor was involved in both intrusions."</p><aside class="injection"><div class="article-story-promo ezp-inbody-promo anonymous" data-widget-name="slot-e">
<div class="title">Recommended</div>
<div class="ezv-listing ezc-csm-story  with-thumbnail ezws-3"><a title="Slow and small, drones find cracks in Israel’s high-tech air defenses" class="ezc-csm-story-link" href="/World/Middle-East/2024/1016/israel-hezbollah-drones-missile-defense"><div class="story-thumbnail square_200x200"><img class=" lazyload" data-src="//images.csmonitor.com/csm/2024/10/1016%20ODRONES%20lede.jpg?alias=square_200x200" alt=""></div>
<div class="story-detail">
<span class="kicker value_kicker">Innovation</span><h3 class="story-headline"><span class="story_link">Slow and small, drones find cracks in Israel’s high-tech air defenses</span></h3>
</div></a></div>
</div></aside><p>Stewart, who has spent the past 20 months cataloging the digital infrastructure of the two groups, is staggered by the number of personnel that must be involved. He has discovered hundreds of families of custom made malware, suggesting hundreds of employees and maybe even thousands – some hackers, but many more researchers that support their activities, as well as analysts to cull and process the stolen information.</p><aside class="injection" data-widget-name="body-last-injection">

		</div></aside><p>It suggests a state-supported or at least state-tolerated institution of large and well-funded proportions. Supporting this conclusion, he says, is the fact that the pair of attackers routinely target entire industry groups, not just individual companies.</p><p>"Everyone that does cybersecurity for a living should know about these two groups," Stewart says. "It's taken about five years for experts to understand what's really going on – and it's pretty well understood now. But people in our industry don't share this kind of information very freely so it's hard to get up to speed. Just getting antivirus vendors to agree on a name would be a huge leap."</p>

<section id="marks-note" class="hide row hide-for-paywall anonymous">
	<div class="container small-11 large-9 small-centered columns">
		<div class="editor ezc-staff large-3 columns text-center" data-widget-name="ddp-editor-mugshot">
			<a href="/About/People/Mark-Sappenfield" class="staff-name with-staff-drawing" target="_blank">
				<img src="//images.csmonitor.com/csm/2019/11/1025853_6_Mark-Sappenfield-drawing_standard.png?alias=square_400x400" alt="">
				<span>Mark Sappenfield</span>
			</a>
			<div class="staffline">Editor</div>
		</div>
		<div class="note small-centered small-11 medium-12 large-9 large-uncentered columns">
			<p>Dear Reader,</p>
			<p>About a year ago, I happened upon this statement about the Monitor in the Harvard Business Review – under the charming heading of “do things that don’t interest you”:</p>
			<p>“Many things that end up” being meaningful, writes social scientist Joseph Grenny, “have come from conference workshops, articles, or online videos that began as a chore and ended with an insight. My work in Kenya, for example, was heavily influenced by a Christian Science Monitor article I had forced myself to read 10 years earlier. Sometimes, we call things ‘boring’ simply because they lie outside the box we are currently in.”</p>
			<p>If you were to come up with a punchline to a joke about the Monitor, that would probably be it. We’re seen as being global, fair, insightful, and perhaps a bit too earnest. We’re the bran muffin of journalism.</p>
			<p>But you know what? We change lives. And I’m going to argue that we change lives precisely because we force open that too-small box that most human beings think they live in.</p>
			<p>The Monitor is a peculiar little publication that’s hard for the world to figure out. We’re run by a church, but we’re not only for church members and we’re not about converting people. We’re known as being fair even as the world becomes as polarized as at any time since the newspaper’s founding in 1908.</p>
			<p>We have a mission beyond circulation, we want to bridge divides. We’re about kicking down the door of thought everywhere and saying, “You are bigger and more capable than you realize. And we can prove it.”</p>
			<p>If you’re looking for bran muffin  journalism, you can subscribe to the Monitor for $15. You’ll get the Monitor Weekly magazine, the Monitor Daily email, and unlimited access to CSMonitor.com.</p>
		</div>
		<div class="text-center">
			<p><a href="/subscribe" class="button_link"><span>Subscribe to insightful journalism</span></a></p>
		</div>
	</div>
</section>
		</div>
	</div>
</section>

<script>

	function submitForm( form )
	{
		let newsletterEmailField = form.querySelector('input[type="email"]');

		if (newsletterEmailField !== undefined )
		{
			let newsletterEmail = newsletterEmailField.value,
				rootURL = '/monitornewsletters?email=',
				newsletterSections = getCheckedNewsletters(form),
				trackingParam = getParam(form);

			if ( newsletterEmail !== undefined )
			{
				let signUpURL = rootURL + encodeURIComponent(newsletterEmail) + newsletterSections + trackingParam;
				window.location = signUpURL;
			}
		}
	}

	function removeMultipleListings()
	{
		let listings = document.querySelectorAll('#newsletter-listing');
		if ( listings.length > 1 )
		{
			for(let x=1; x<listings.length; x++)
			{
				listings[x].remove();
			}
		}
	}

	function getCheckedNewsletters( form )
	{
		let newsletterSections = '';
		if( form.hasAttribute('data-selection') )
		{
			let dataSelection = form.getAttribute('data-selection');
			if(dataSelection.length > 0)
			{
				dataSelection.split(' ').forEach( newsletter =>
				{
					newsletterSections += `&${newsletter}=true`;
				})
			}
		}
		return newsletterSections;
	}

	function getParam( form )
	{
		let param = setDefaultParam( form.parentElement );
		let newsletterBannerParent = form.parentElement.parentElement;
		if ( newsletterBannerParent.classList.contains( 'param-added' ) )
		{
			param = '&icid=mkt:web:' + newsletterBannerParent.getAttribute('data-param');
		}
		return param;
	}

	function setDefaultParam( formContainer )
	{
		let defaultParam = '&icid=mkt:web:banner',
			pageBody = document.querySelector('body');

		if ( formContainer )
		{
			if ( formContainer.classList.contains( 'books' ) )
			{
				defaultParam = '&icid=mkt:web:books';
			}
			else if ( formContainer.classList.contains( 'politics' ) )
			{
				defaultParam = '&icid=mkt:web:politics';
			}
			else if ( formContainer.classList.contains( 'culture-learning' ) )
			{
				defaultParam = '&icid=mkt:web:culture-learning';
			}
			else if ( formContainer.classList.contains( 'science' ) )
			{
				defaultParam = '&icid=mkt:web:science-nature';
			}
			else if ( formContainer.classList.contains( 'csperspective' ) )
			{
				defaultParam = '&icid=mkt:web:csp';
			}
			else if ( formContainer.classList.contains( 'commentary' ) )
			{
				defaultParam = '&icid=mkt:web:commentary';
			}
			else if ( formContainer.classList.contains( 'highlights' ) )
			{
				defaultParam = '&icid=mkt:web:highlights';
			}
		}

		if ( pageBody.classList.contains( 'ezc-frontpage' ) )
		{
			defaultParam = '&icid=mkt:web:frontpage';
		}
		return defaultParam;
	}

	function addFormEventListener()
	{
		let newsletterBanners = document.querySelectorAll('.newsletter-banner:not(.subscribe):not(.free-trial) form');
		newsletterBanners.forEach( newsletterBanner =>
		{
			if( newsletterBanner.getAttribute('sub-event') !== 'true' )
			{
				newsletterBanner.addEventListener( 'submit', ( e ) =>
				{
					e.preventDefault();
					submitForm( newsletterBanner );
					newsletterBanner.innerHTML = '<div style="font-weight:600;" class="text-center">Thank you for signing up for a free Monitor Newsletter!</div>';
				});
				newsletterBanner.setAttribute('sub-event','true');
			}
		});
	}

	if ( window.location.href.indexOf('kwc2c') > -1 )
	{
		let allNewslettersBanners = document.querySelectorAll(".newsletter-banner");
		allNewslettersBanners.remove();
	}


	document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', () =>
	{
		removeMultipleListings();
		addFormEventListener();
		try
		{
			let salesforce_id = _satellite.getVar('Query String - SFMC Subscriber ID');
			if ( salesforce_id )
			{
				let pagePath = csmJs.pageData.sections;

				if ( pagePath.indexOf( 'Books' ) > -1 )
				{
					csmJs.cta.changeBanner( 'books' );
				}
				else if ( pagePath.indexOf( 'Politics' ) > -1 )
				{
					csmJs.cta.changeBanner( 'politics' );
				}
				else if ( pagePath.indexOf( 'Education' ) > -1 ||
					pagePath.indexOf( 'The Culture' ) > -1 )
				{
					csmJs.cta.changeBanner( 'culture-learning' );
				}
				else if ( pagePath.indexOf( 'Science' ) > -1 ||
					pagePath.indexOf( 'Environment' ) > -1 ||
					pagePath.indexOf( 'Technology' ) > -1 )
				{
					csmJs.cta.changeBanner( 'science' );
				}
				else if ( pagePath.indexOf( 'A Christian Science Perspective' ) > -1 )
				{
					csmJs.cta.changeBanner( 'csperspective' );
				}
				else if ( pagePath.indexOf( 'Commentary' ) > -1 )
				{
					csmJs.cta.changeBanner( 'commentary' );
				}
				else
				{
					csmJs.cta.changeBanner( 'highlights' );
				}
			}
		}
		catch ( error )
		{
			console.warn( error );
		}
	}, false);
</script>
		</div>
</div>
